DOC.HEAD: Dollar Edges Down, Stocks Lose
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index ended seven days of gains and the dollar edged down against the Japanese yen today, as markets were stirred by rumors of an impending discount rate increase. The dollar ended trading at 143.80 yen, down 0.42 yen from Monday's 144.22-yen close. It opened at 143.55 yen and ranged between 143.15 and 143.97 yen. ``Trading was hectic because of the rumor,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. In spot active trading in which an estimated $10.8 billion traded hands, Japanese investors sold the dollar and the West German mark to buy the yen during morning trading. In the afternoon they bought the currencies back after Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto denied the reports of an interest rate increase. Hashimoto said the current Japanese economic situation did not require another discount rate hike because of stable prices, but that exchange rate levels required watching. The Bank of Japan has raised its discount rate twice this year to the current 3.75 percent. Following Hashimoto's remarks, Bank of Japan official Tatsuya Tamura said in a statement that government interest rate policy was ``a blank slate.'' The Yomiuri Shimbun and the Asahi Shimbun, Japan's two largest newspapers, reported today that the Bank of Japan would hike its official discount rate by 0.5 percentage points to 4.25 percent by this weekend. Ms. Takeuchi said the government's denial made the market players shift their attention from domestic to U.S. monetary policy, ``because the market now expects the hike will be postponed at least until after February, when (Japanese) national elections are expected.'' The official discount rate is the rate the central bank charges on its loans to commercial banks, which often influences other interest rates. Higher interest rates make a country's currency more attractive to currency investors, but discourages stock investors. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 147.08 points, or 0.38 percent, closing at 38,489.10. It had gained 315.14 points to a record-high close of 38,586.18 on Monday. Dealers attributed the loss to the discount rate rumors. ``Until the bank actually raises the rate, the market will move nervously every time somebody spreads the rumor in the market,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a Daiwa Securities dealer. ``Since the market already has begun reacting to the rumors, the impact will be minimal if and when the central bank actually announces a hike,'' said Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities. ``We consider today's decline small, considering the negative impact of the rumor,'' he said. Volume on the market's first section was an estimated 900 million shares, up from Monday's 850 million shares.
